title: Kangaroos are resorting to eating the stomachs and intestines of their dead relatives due to drought
text:
Desperate and starving kangaroos are resorting to eating the stomachs and intestines of their dead relatives.

Ecologists believe the prolonged drought has led to the mass deaths of the overabundant marsupial across South Australia.

Independent ecologist John Read told the ABC there had had been a 'huge die-off' of kangaroos during the past year.

Desperate and starving kangaroos are resorting to eating the stomachs and intestines of their dead relatives, as severe drought kills millions of the species. Pictured: A dead kangaroo near an empty water trough in Wilcannia, New South Wales on August 19, 2018

'So throughout central Australia, millions of kangaroos basically starved to death and people would have seen them dying on the roads and off the roads,' Dr Read said.

Katherine Moseby, ecologist at the University of New South Wales, said that while working in arid zones and at Flinders Ranges she saw kangaroos desperately looking for meals.

'We were seeing them going into the public toilets and eating toilet paper,' Dr Moseby said.

'We're even witnessing them eating the stomachs of dead kangaroos on the side of the road, trying to get some nutrition out of the corpses. It was really quite upsetting and quite horrible to watch.'

Mr Read said acacia, pine and sandalwood trees had also been dying amid the South Australian heatwave.

He said it was 'shocking' to learn that acacia - which had lived for hundreds of years - was dying.

Despite the deaths of kangaroos in the eastern states, the numbers in Western Australia have boomed.

West Australia is not facing the same drought conditions as experienced elsewhere across the country.

authors: Zoe Zaczek For Daily Mail Australia
